content: The Act may be cited as the "Asthma Awareness, Education and Treatment Act of 1999". The Congress finds that asthma affects millions of Americans, with a significant impact on children. Allergies, including allergic asthma, also affect a large portion of the population. Asthma is a common respiratory disease in children, leading to school absenteeism and preventable hospitalizations. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly, especially among preschool children. Women and low-income families are more likely to be affected by asthma. The prevalence of asthma is higher in low-income families, with 79.2 out of 1,000 individuals under 45 in families earning less than $10,000 annually having asthma. In 1997, over 5,000 Americans died from asthma attacks, with African Americans having a higher average death rate than Caucasians. Asthma costs the US over $12 billion annually, and the rising prevalence will lead to even higher costs in the future. African Americans are five times more likely to have asthma compared to other groups. Exercise can improve the well-being of children, including self-esteem, and help manage asthma. African Americans have higher asthma death rates and are more likely to seek emergency care. Asthma costs the US $12 billion annually, with rising prevalence leading to even higher costs in the future. SEC. 3. GRANTS FOR PROJECTS FOR ASTHMA-RELATED ACTIVITIES FOR LOW-INCOME COMMUNITIES. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may grant funds to public and nonprofit entities for projects in low-income communities focusing on asthma, allergies, and respiratory issues. This includes screenings, education, and workshops for individuals like parents, teachers, and school nurses. The Secretary ensures comprehensive screenings and referrals for asthma, allergies, and respiratory problems in various settings including medical facilities, schools, community centers, and government offices. The Secretary provides information and education on asthma, allergies, and respiratory problems in appropriate language and cultural context, focusing on symptoms, prevention, and management of the conditions. The Secretary provides information and education on asthma, allergies, and respiratory problems, emphasizing prevention and management, including avoiding triggers, medication options, and the importance of physical activity for asthmatic children. Evaluation of projects under this subsection is also conducted. Settings for information and education include traditional and nontraditional settings. The Secretary evaluates projects under subsection (a) to determine the impact on children receiving screenings and referrals, the effectiveness of asthma prevention and management, and the materials used for information and education. Grants under subsection (a) require applicants to be community-based organizations serving low-income communities. The Secretary evaluates projects to assess their impact on children's health and asthma prevention. Grants require applicants to involve low-income community organizations. To receive a grant, applicants must submit a detailed application to the Secretary. $8,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2000, with additional funding for subsequent years. The National Media Campaign provides asthma-related information. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may award contracts for a national media campaign on asthma, allergies, and respiratory problems, prioritizing children. The campaign must provide information on prevention and management of these conditions, as well as information on available community programs. The campaign provides information on programs for screenings, referrals, and treatment in the community. It is conducted in a culturally appropriate language. $600,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2000, with additional funding for subsequent years. SEC. 5. TAX CREDIT FOR DONATIONS OF PEST CONTROL AND CLIMATE CONTROL SERVICES. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide a tax credit for donations of pest control and climate control services. Taxpayers providing pest control or climate control services can receive a donation credit equal to 10% of costs incurred for qualified services in public housing or multifamily residential rental properties. The United States Housing Act of 1937 allows for pest control and climate control services in public housing or multifamily residential rental properties with occupants below 200 percent of the poverty line. Services must be part of a good faith effort and verified by the Secretary. Pest control services include eliminating cockroaches, dust mites, animal dander, and mold, while climate control services aim to improve ventilation and temperature control. The amendment to the United States Housing Act of 1937 includes provisions for pest control and climate control services in public housing or multifamily residential rental properties. The amendment specifies that taxpayers engaged in providing these services can claim a donation credit under section 45D of the tax code. Additionally, there are conforming amendments to sections 38(b) and 39(d) of the tax code related to unused credits. The tax code is amended to disallow carryback of section 45D credit before January 1, 2000. The tax code is amended to disallow carryback of section 45D credit before January 1, 2000. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1999. Research on the relationship between air pollutants and asthma-related problems is also addressed. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with the EPA, will conduct research to determine the link between air pollutants and asthma, allergies, and respiratory issues. Clinical research will prioritize evaluating relevant populations for this purpose. The research will focus on individuals in communities with family incomes at or below 200 percent of the poverty line. SEC. 7. COORDINATION OF FEDERAL ACTIVITIES TO ADDRESS ASTHMA-RELATED HEALTH CARE NEEDS. The Director of the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute will identify federal programs for asthma, develop a federal response plan, and submit recommendations to Congress for improving coordination. The Department of Housing and Urban Development will have a representative on the coordinating committee. The National Asthma Education Prevention Program Coordinating Committee will receive $5,000,000 from the National Institutes of Health for fiscal years 2000 through 2004 to carry out specified tasks. SEC. 8. COMPILATION OF DATA BY CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION. The Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, in consultation with the National Asthma Education Prevention Program Coordinating Committee, conducts local asthma surveillance activities to collect data on asthma prevalence, severity, and management. This includes telephone surveys and health care facility surveillance. They also compile and publish data on the prevalence of children with asthma and childhood mortality rates associated with asthma nationally and by state.
